en.UI_LEVEL_COMPLETE: Good Job! All is in balance!
en.MSG_END_A: CONGRATULATIONS! TAP TO CONTINUE TO NEXT ECOSYSTEM
en.MSG_END_B: CONGRATULATIONS! TAP TO CONTINUE TO SEE RESULTS
en.ROCK_ERROR_01: Rocks are a non-living thing, they don't need air, food or water.
en.ROCK_ERROR_02: Rocks are a non-living thing, they don't grow and don't reproduce.
en.ERROR_INVALID_01: This living thing cannot survive here, remove it from the board.
en.ERROR_INVALID_02: There is no food for this living thing, remove it from the board.
en.ERROR_INVALID_03: The weather is not good for this living thing, remove it from the board.
en.INFO_VIDEO_2_C: They use, rearrange, and ultimately decompose the complex organic materials built up by the autotrophs.
en.INFO_VIDEO_3_E: For example, a typical food chain in a grassland might be grass (producer) -> mouse (primary consumer) -> snake (secondary consumer) -> hawk (tertiary consumer).
en.INFO_VIDEO_1_D: They can use the energy of sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into simple, energy-rich carbohydrates.
en.INFO_VIDEO_2_A: Organic matter generated by autotrophs directly or indirectly sustains heterotrophic organisms.
en.INFO_VIDEO_5_A: Ecosystems can be very large or very small.
en.INFO_VIDEO_1_C: Consisting largely of green vegetation, these organisms are capable of photosynthesis.
en.INFO_VIDEO_6_A: Ecosystems are often connected in a larger biome.
en.INFO_VIDEO_5_C: Herbivores such as abalone eat the seaweed.
en.INFO_VIDEO_2_B: Heterotrophs are the consumers of the ecosystem. They cannot make their own food.
en.INFO_VIDEO_4_B: Ecosystems contain living parts that include plants, animals, and other organisms. they also include nonliving parts that include rocks, temperature, and humidity.
en.INFO_VIDEO_5_D: Carnivores, such as sea stars, eat other animals in the tide pool, such as clams or mussels.
en.INFO_VIDEO_3_B: Animals are consumers. They do not produce energy. They get energy by eating producers.
en.INFO_VIDEO_4_C: Biotic factors include plants, animals, and other organisms.
en.INFO_VIDEO_6_B: Biomes are large sections of land, sea, or atmosphere. Forests, ponds, reefs, and tundra are all types of biomes, for example.
en.INFO_VIDEO_5_B: Tide pools, the ponds left by the ocean as the tide goes out, are complete, tiny ecosystems. Tide pools contain seaweed, a kind of algae, which uses photosynthesis to create food.
en.INFO_VIDEO_2_D: All animals and fungi are heterotrophs, as are most bacteria and many other microorganisms.
en.INFO_VIDEO_3_F: The final link in all food chains is made up of decomposers, which are heterotrophs that break down dead organisms and organic wastes.
en.INFO_VIDEO_3_A: Plants are producers. They take energy from the Sun to make food for other living things.
en.INFO_VIDEO_1_A: The fundamental source of energy in almost all ecosystems is radiant energy from the Sun.
en.INFO_VIDEO_4_A: An ecosystem is a geographic area where plants, animals, and other organisms, as well as weather and landscape, work together to form a bubble of life.
en.INFO_VIDEO_3_C: Decomposers break down dead organisms and organic wastes.
en.INFO_VIDEO_3_D: The movement of organic matter and energy from the producer level through various consumer levels makes up a food chain.
en.ERROR_NO_BALANCE: If an ecosystem isn't balanced, it stops working!
en.ERROR_BALANCE_1: Reaching the perfect balance line, the living things will be able to be born, grow and reproduce.
en.ERROR_BALANCE_2: You have to reach the perfect balance line.
en.ERROR_BALANCE_3: Each animal and plant must reach the green line!
en.ERROR_BALANCE_4: Check the climate, it must be correct for this ecosystem.
en.ERROR_BALANCE_5: Remove/Add animals or plants from the food chain.
en.ERROR_BALANCE_6: Living things need an ecosystem with perfect balance to be able to be born, grow and reproduce.
en.TUTO_A: This is the line of balance!
en.TUTO_B: You need to balance your ecosystem by adding elements!
en.INFO_VIDEO_4_D: Abiotic factors include rocks, temperature, and humidity.
en.INFO_VIDEO_1_B: The energy of sunlight is used by the ecosystem's autotrophic, or self-sustaining, organisms.
en.INTRO_V_2: Help us maintain the balance of ecosystems so that living things continue to exist! The balance is maintained thanks to the food chains. Don't you know what a food chain is? Let's check!
en.INTRO_VIDEO_1: The sun provides energy through its light! Plants use that energy through photosynthesis, like this bush and tree.
en.INTRO_VIDEO_2: Plants are producers. They produce their own food! They also make food for other living things. Like this apple tree.
en.INTRO_VIDEO_3: Animals are consumers, they cannot make their own food, they eat. Some consumers are herbivores, that means they can only eat plants, like this rabbit.
en.INTRO_VIDEO_4: Some consumers eat meat but can also be omnivorous, that means they can eat meat and plants, like this fox.
en.INTRO_VIDEO_5: Decomposers, like this mushroom, takes energy decomposing organic materials like remains of the apple. This happens at any level of the food chain.
en.INTRO_VIDEO_6: Together, plants and animals create a food chain! There must be a quantity of each living thing that participates in the food chain to keep the ecosystem balanced!
